title: Sliding Block Travelling Around a Loop

content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A block of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> starts from rest at point <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and travels with negligible friction through the loop onto a horizontal surface, where the block makes contact with a spring of spring constant <math alttext="k equals the fraction m g, over 2 R, end fraction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. All motion of the spring is in the horizontal direction. Point <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is the highest point on the loop, and point <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is the rightmost point on the loop. Express all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. The arrow must start on and point away from the dot. Justify your answer.
